# The First Appendix

## Study 1


### Data exclusion

Participants will be excluded from analyses if any of the following:

-   failed attention check,

-   failed comprehension check,

-   missing data on model-relevant variables

-   score of \<= 3 on attention boost item

**ATTENTION CHECK:**

"To help us understand how people think about different activities,
please answer this question correctly. Specifically, we are interested
in whether you actually take the time to read the directions; if not,
the results of your responses would not be very useful. To show that you
have read the instructions carefully, please ignore the items below
about activities and instead select the option "other," and type "yes"
in field below.

'Based on the information in the preceding paragraph, which of these
activities do you engage in most regularly?'
Watching Athletics
Attending Cultural Events
Participating in Athletics
Reading Outside of Work or School
Watching Movies
Travel
Religious Activities
Needlework
Cooking
Gardening
Computer Games
Hiking
Board or Card Games
Other:"

**COMPREHENSION CHECK:**
"What best describes your role in this study?

-   Deciding whether to accept an offer

-   Placing a bid

-   \*\*Deciding whether to purchase a security product\*\* - CORRECT

-   Donating funds to a shared project"

**ATTENTION CHECK/BOOSTER**

-   " It is important for the quality of our research that participants focus as they complete this short study. Please close any other tabs or windows that you might have open, turn off any music or distracting media, and give this study your full attention.

Please indicate your likelihood of paying full attention during this study:" [1: Extremely Unlikely... 7: Extremely Likely]

Given the bounded nature of the minimum and maximum values for the variables in the experimental designs, outliers are considered legitimate values and will not be deleted.

## Study 3

### Notes on pre-registered plan

An ordinal regression carries an assumption of proportional odds: that the predictors' effects are consistent across the different levels of the dependent variable. Currently, we are not aware of any available methods for testing the proportional odds assumption for a mixed ordinal regression; existing methods only serve as a test on single-level data. As such, we will attempt to test this assumption using multiple logistic regressions, conducted for each rank threshold (e.g., 0\|1, 1\|2, 2\|3). Since inequality is the major predictor of interest, only this coefficient will be compared across logistic models, which will help attenuate the impact of Type I errors. The proportional odds assumption will be deemed as violated if the regression coefficients for inequality are significantly different across models. If there is a significant difference amongst the predictors (suggesting a violation of the proportional odds assumption), then the separate logistic regressions will be presented as the primary analysis instead.



Main analyses will be conducted using the r package ordinal, with the following mixed model specification:

> `ordered(security_winz) ~ gini_2004_6_cent + gdppc_2004_6_scale + victim_nation_cent + num_victim_5yr + age_cent + employed + male + (1 | country)`






#### Robustness checks

1) A supplementary analysis will be conducted on a different sweep period of the ICVS (1999-2003). Anticipated n = 70,264 (unique participants), with k = 41 countries


<!-- > `r glue::glue_collapse(x = iv_2005_countries, ", ", last = ", and the  ")` -->


2) For the main model, as determined by contingencies, analyses will be repeated with regular (unwinzorized) security_total

In order to test robustness with the same variables: 

the 3) k = 32 data and the 
4) k = 41 data will be run with the following reduced model (excluding partnered, employed, and housing)

`ordered(security_winz) ~ gini_2004_6_cent + gdppc_2004_6_scale + victim_nation_cent + num_victim_5yr + age_cent + male +  (1 | country)`

A sample linear model revealed nonproblematic levels of multicollinearity, maximum VIF of `r round(max(sec_lmer1_iv_vif),2)` 

```{r vif-values, eval =F}
c(sec_lmer1_iv_vif,sec_lmer1_poly_int_vif, sec_lmer1_int_vif,sec_lmer1_poly_vif)
```


For all of these models, analyses will be repeated with winzorized level-2 variables:

5) regular k = 32 model
6) unwinzorized security_total k = 32 model
7) full k = 41 model
8) small k = 32 model
9) small k = 41 model

For values within reasonable scope of response variables, outliers are considered legitimate values and will not be deleted. Outliers will be defined using a sample linear model for level-2 variables, and observations flagged as outliers if their residuals have a cook's distance value of \> 4/n will have those predictor variables winzorized (as they are expected to be legitimate values). As a robustness check, analyses will be repeated with influential observations being winzorized at the dependent variable to the 5th and 95th percentile values. Influential observations will be flagged as having model residuals' cook's distance values exceeding the threshold 4/n; where n = \# of observations.


<!-- In addition, supplementary analyses will assess whether the effects of inequality persist in a smaller, variable-maximizing dataset (`r sum(summary(iv_2005_mod$country)>0)` countries, `r format(nrow(iv_2005_mod), big.mark = ",", scientific = FALSE)` respondents). -->

<!-- The robustness of the mixed model results will be examined by repeating the analyses on the smaller subsample of observations (k = 28, and n = 48,178), both with the same variables, and with additional variables. We will report on any changes in the patterns of significance. -->




Degrees of freedom were calculated using methods defined in @snijders2011

level 1: *M*-*r*-1

level 2: *N*-*q*-1

*M*: total number of level-one units, *r*: total number of explanatory variables, *N*: number of level-two units, *q*: number of level-2 predictors

```{r s3-logistic-scaled-robust, eval=T}
sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1 <- round_df2(data.frame(sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy))

sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1 <- data.frame(sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1) %>%
  dplyr::rename(
    "SE" = std.error,
    "95\\% CI" = CI95,
    "\\textit{z}" = z_score,
    "\\textit{p}" = p_value,
    "\\textit{b}" = estimate
    )

sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1 <- subset(sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1, select = -c(SE,ci95_lo,ci95_hi,lvl,df))


sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term <- ifelse(sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "gini_2004_6_scale" | sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "gini_2004_6_cent" | sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "gini_1999_03_scale" | sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "gini_1999_03_cent", "Nation gini",
                                         ifelse(sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "gdppc_2004_6_scale" | sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "gdppc_2004_6_cent" | sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "gdppc_1999_03_scale" | sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "gdppc_1999_03_cent","Nation GDP per-capita",
                                                
                                                ifelse(sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "victim_nation_cent","Nation-level victimization",
                                                       ifelse(sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "age_num" | sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "age_cent" | sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "age_scale", "Age",
                                                              ifelse(sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "num_victim_5yr","Individual victimizations",
                                                                     ifelse(sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "employed1", "Employed", 
                                                                            ifelse(sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "male1","Male",ifelse(sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "other_house","Other house type", ifelse(sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "partnered1","Partnered", ifelse(sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term == "house","House",sec_mw100_log_robust_scale_tidy1$term)))))
                                                                     )
                                                              )
                                                  
                                                )
                                                )
                                         )

mlog_issues <- c(m100_log_nonconverge,m100_log_scale_nonconverge,m100_log_robust_nonconverge,m100_log_robust_scale_nonconverge)
mord_issues <- c(m100_ord_nonconverge,m100_ord_scale_nonconverge,m100_ord_nonconverge_robust,m100_ord_scale_nonconverge_robust)
wlog_issues <- c(mw100_log_nonconverge,mw100_log_scale_nonconverge,mw100_log_robust_nonconverge,mw100_log_robust_scale_nonconverge)
word_issues <- c(mw100_ord_nonconverge,mw100_ord_scale_nonconverge,NA,NA)

converg_tab <- rbind(mlog_issues,mord_issues,wlog_issues,word_issues)

row.names(converg_tab) <- log_ord

converg_tab_k <- knitr::kable(converg_tab, caption = "Convergence issues across 100 analyses for 2004-06 period",
                         col.names = models,
                         row.names = T,
                         booktabs = T,
                         linesep = "") %>%
kable_styling(latex_options = c(
  # "striped", 
  "hold_position"))

converg_tab_k
```

sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1 <- round_df2(data.frame(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy))


sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1 <- data.frame(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1) %>%
  dplyr::rename(
    "SE" = std.error,
    "95\\% CI" = CI95,
    "\\textit{z}" = z_score,
    "\\textit{p}" = p_value,
    "\\textit{b}" = estimate
    )

sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1 <- subset(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1, select = -c(SE,ci95_lo,ci95_hi,lvl,df))


sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term <- ifelse(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "gini_2004_6_scale" | sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "gini_2004_6_cent" | sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "gini_1999_03_scale" | sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "gini_1999_03_cent", "Nation gini",
                                         ifelse(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "gdppc_2004_6_scale" | sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "gdppc_2004_6_cent" | sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "gdppc_1999_03_scale" | sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "gdppc_1999_03_cent","Nation GDP per-capita",
                                                
                                                ifelse(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "victim_nation_cent","Nation-level victimization",
                                                       ifelse(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "age_num" | sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "age_cent" | sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "age_scale", "Age",
                                                              ifelse(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "num_victim_5yr","Individual victimizations",
                                                                     ifelse(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "employed1", "Employed", 
                                                                            ifelse(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "male1","Male",ifelse(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "other_house","Other house type", ifelse(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "partnered1","Partnered", ifelse(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term == "house","House",sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1$term)))))
                                                                     )
                                                              )
                                                       )
                                                )
                                         )
knitr::kable(sec_mw100_ord_drop_tidy1,
             format='latex',
             escape = FALSE,
             align = "lcccccc",
             caption = 'Study 3, mixed weighted ordinal regression, 2004-6 period.',
             booktabs = TRUE,
             linesep = "",
             # ,format.args=list(floating=TRUE)
             # escape = FALSE
             ) %>%
kable_styling(latex_options = c(
  # "striped", 
  "hold_position"))
